title: MLB DFS Plays: Friday 9/27
text:
This article will outline the best daily fantasy MLB plays of the day at every position. We will take a comprehensive look to uncover these core recommendations, factoring respective salaries into the analysis.

Please note, these player picks were organized early in the day. For MLB contests, always check lineups and weather closer to game time. Rain, wind, or unexpected managerial decisions could open up additional sources of value. Be sure to keep an eye on the MLB Headlines and Injuries desk.

We’re cooking with 14 games tonight.

Scroll to continue with content Ad

PITCHER

Walker Buehler – Los Angeles Dodgers (at Giants)

This might be a good night to bet on value plays like Velasquez, Lopez, and Eovaldi. The reason is that playoff bound clubs with nothing left to play for have the best pitchers in the slate. We’re likely to see artificially shortened outings. However, despite losing some of the ceiling on Buehler, it’s still hard to pass up Buehler at Oracle Park. He’ll face a terrible offense at a pitcher friendly venue. We should get something like six innings and seven strikeouts. Those contest leading point totals we usually dream about when rostering Buehler may be out of reach, but he’s the safest pick for an above average performance.

Also Consider: Vince Velasquez (value), Pablo Lopez (value), Nathan Eovaldi (value), James Paxton, Jose Berrios

CATCHER / FIRST BASE

Yasmani Grandal – Milwaukee Brewers (at Chi Chi Gonzalez)

Story continues

Yep, we’re finishing up 2019 with a Coors Field series. Grab any and all Brewers who fit into your lineup. Gonzalez is on a shockingly successful streak of four straight solid outings – two on the road against the Dodgers and two at home. There’s no obvious reason to believe he’s improved. This looks more like a “blind squirrel” situation. It’s likely the Brewers will put up at least half a dozen runs tonight. With Christian Yelich waylaid, Grandal is arguably their best hitter. He bats second. His patient and powerful approach tends to produce extreme outcomes. He’s likely to at least walk a time or two, and he also carries a one-in-four chance to homer.

Also Consider: Mitch Garver, Sean Murphy (value), Travis d’Arnaud (value), Pete Alonso, Cody Bellinger, Max Muncy (value), Eric Thames, Edwin Encarnacion

SECOND BASE

Gleyber Torres – New York Yankees (at Joe Palumbo)

If you’re not playing Coors Field, the Yankees stack is looking second-best. They’re visiting Globe Life park which is extremely offense-oriented at this time of year. More to the point, southpaw Joe Palumbo has performed terribly in a small sample of major league work. In particular, Palumbo has struggled with home runs (four in 13.2 innings). He’ll probably only throw two to three innings, but that just means Torres and friends will see squishy relievers. Torres is one hot series away from reaching the 40-homer plateau. His batted ball profile matches up well against Palumbo’s.

Consider a flexible approach to selecting your second baseman tonight. It’s an extremely deep position with bargain plays extending well beyond those listed below.

Also Consider: Max Muncy (value), Mike Moustakas, Keston Hiura, Nick Solak (value), DJ LeMahieu, Ryan McMahon, Jose Altuve, Joey Wendle (value)

THIRD BASE

Eugenio Suarez – Pittsburgh Pirates (at Steven Brault)

Depending on the platform you play, second and third base may have a lot of overlap. Considering the scalding power binge he’s on, Suarez is shockingly cheap. Brault is a left-handed ground ball pitcher who struggles versus right-handed hitters. Suarez is a fly ball-hitting lefty masher. While PNC Park is pitcher friendly, ballparks aren’t as much of a consideration in this juiced-ball fueled season. Suarez projects for just under one-third of a homer.

Also Consider: Mike Moustakas, Rafael Devers, Nolan Arenado, Anthony Rendon, Matt Chapman (value), Nick Solak (value), Joey Wendle (value), Gio Urshela

SHORTSTOP

Marcus Semien – Oakland Athletics (at Justus Sheffield)

Semien is a classic lefty-killer although he’s posted neutral platoon splits in this breakout season. Sheffield is an unusual ground ball pitcher with shaky command. Semien’s discipline, high contact rate, and ability to jump on mistakes should serve him well in this matchup. Once the Athletics chase Sheffield, they’ll feast on the Mariners bullpen. This game has playoff implications – the A’s are just one game up on the Rays to host the Wild Card game. Semien projects for a little under one-quarter of a homer.

Also Consider: Gleyber Torres, Trevor Story, Alex Bregman, Francisco Lindor, Manny Machado (value)

OUTFIELD

Trent Grisham – Milwaukee Brewers (at Chi Chi Gonzalez)

Outfield is an excellent position to pack in Coors Field bats. Grisham is among the pricier options in the slate tonight, but he’s still a bargain so long as he’s batting leadoff. With a patient approach that sometimes crosses the border into outright passivity, he should do well against a poor-command pitcher like Gonzalez. He also makes high quality contact and can hit for power. It’s the total package. If he bats down in the order, he’ll still be borderline usable.

Sam Hilliard – Colorado Rockies (vs Zach Davies)

Let’s not neglect Rockies bats. You know all the big names. Hilliard is a discount power source. After hitting 35 home runs with 22 steals at Triple-A, he’s hammered six deep shots in 76 major league plate appearances (no steals as yet). The 25-year-old is extremely strikeout prone, but it’s not as if Davies induces many whiffs. In fact, he’s a pitch-to-contact guy at sea level. He’ll truly struggle to miss bats at elevation.

Also Consider: Aaron Judge (value), J.D. Martinez (value), Charlie Blackmon, Mookie Betts, Juan Soto (value), Austin Meadows, Aristides Aquino, Tommy Pham (value), Josh Rojas (value)
